questions.text: Which congenital heart disease is associated with the same saturation in all 4 chambers of the heart?
questions.solution:
The duct dependent lesions cause shunting of blood from right to left leading to difference in limb saturations.

However, in cardiac lesions causing complete mixing of blood like in TAPVC and Truncus arteriosus the limb saturation is low equally in all limbs (i.e., no differential cyanosis

Analysis of Other Options:

  • (A) TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): There is no mixing unless associated with an atrial or ventricular septal defect, so oxygen saturation differs across chambers.
  • (B) TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): Significant right-to-left shunting leads to hypoxemia but not equal saturation in all chambers.
  • (D) Tricuspid Atresia: Oxygenation varies depending on the associated defects (e.g., ASD, VSD), so saturation is not uniform.

Key Point: In TAPVC, because of the complete mixing of blood, all chambers of the heart show the same (reduced) oxygen saturation.


Reference: Cloherty and Starks manual of neonatal care, SA ed., pg. 574

questions.text: A 14 days-old neonate who had bilateral conjunctivitis, now has a cough with chest infiltrates. Which among the following could be the causative organism?
questions.solution:
• Chlamydia trachomatis is a common cause of neonatal conjunctivitis and pneumonia due to vertical transmission from an infected mother during vaginal delivery.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Inclusion conjunctivitis: Usually manifests at 5-14 days of life with watery discharge, eyelid swelling, and erythema.
    • Pneumonia: Develops later (typically 4-12 weeks of age) and presents with a staccato cough, tachypnea, and chest infiltrates on imaging.

Other Options:

  • (A) Haemophilus influenzae: Can cause pneumonia or otitis media but is not associated with neonatal conjunctivitis and vertical transmission.
  • (C) Staphylococcus epidermidis: A skin commensal that rarely causes serious neonatal infections.
  • (D) Mycoplasma: Not a typical pathogen in neonates and does not cause conjunctivitis.

Key Point: Neonatal conjunctivitis followed by pneumonia in the first few weeks of life is highly suggestive of Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 1617

questions.text: Arrange in order, the development milestones, and the age by which it is normally achieved
questions.solution:
Transfers objects hand to hand: 5-6 months

Walking 1-2 steps: 12-13 months

Pincer grasp: 9-11 months

social smile: 1-2 months

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 135

questions.text: What is the dose of dexamethasone given for achieving fetal lung maturity?
questions.solution:
A complete course of ANS is considered to be either betamethasone at 12 mg intramuscular (IM) q24h × 2 doses OR dexamethasone 6 mg IM q12h × 4 doses, course completed at least 24 hours before the delivery.

Reference: Cloherty and Starks manual of neonatal care, SA ed., pg. 452

questions.text: Most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in a male child?
questions.solution:
• Posterior Urethral Valves (PUV):
    • The most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male children.
    • A congenital anomaly involving obstructive leaflets in the posterior urethra.
    • Affects 1 in 8,000 male infants.
    • Leads to severe obstructive uropathy, causing bladder dysfunction, hydroureteronephrosis, and potential renal damage.

Other Options:

  • (B) Ureterocele:
    • A congenital anomaly of the ureter, typically associated with ureteral duplication.
    • Can obstruct the ureter but does not cause primary bladder outlet obstruction.
  • (C) Ureteral Atresia:
    • A rare cause of obstruction but primarily affects the ureter, not the bladder outlet.
  • (D) Bladder stone:
    • Can cause bladder outlet obstruction but is far less common in children compared to PUV.

Key Takeaway:


Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2808

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH)?
questions.solution:
Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare disorder characterized by the proliferation of abnormal Langerhans-like cells. The hallmark feature includes the presence of Birbeck granules, which are tennis racket-shaped organelles seen in the cytoplasm of LCH cells under electron microscopy.

Other Characteristics:

  • Eosinophils (A): Eosinophils are often found in LCH lesions, but they are not specific or diagnostic.
  • Histiocytes (C): While Langerhans cells are a type of histiocyte, their presence alone is not specific for LCH.
  • Granulomas (D): Granulomas may be present but are not a defining feature of LCH.

Key Diagnostic Features of LCH:

  1. Immunohistochemistry:
    • LCH cells express CD1a, CD207 (Langerin), and S100.
  2. Birbeck Granules:
    • Found on electron microscopy and are specific to LCH.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2710

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is associated with impaired collagen maturation?
questions.solution:
Scurvy, caused by a deficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), directly affects collagen synthesis and maturation. Vitamin C is a crucial cofactor for the enzymes prolyl hydroxylase and lysyl hydroxylase, which are necessary for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in procollagen. These modifications are essential for stabilizing the collagen triple helix and proper cross-linking of collagen fibers.

Clinical Features of Scurvy:

  • Fragile connective tissues: Poor collagen formation leads to fragile skin, blood vessels, and bones.
  • Skeletal issues: Thin cortex, brittle trabeculae, and poor bone formation.
  • Gum disease: Swelling, bleeding, and receding gums.
  • Impaired wound healing: Due to defective collagen synthesis.

Other Options:

  • Rickets (A): Caused by vitamin D deficiency, it affects bone mineralization but does not impair collagen maturation.
  • Beri Beri (C): Caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, it affects energy metabolism, particularly in the nervous and cardiovascular systems.
  • Pellagra (D): Caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, it results in dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia but does not affect collagen synthesis.

Key Takeaway:

In scurvy, the impaired collagen leads to weakened structural integrity in tissues, making B. Scurvy the correct answer.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 367

questions.text: A child presented with proptosis. You suspect it to be a chloroma. Next best investigation to make the diagnosis (among the following) is?
questions.solution:
Chloroma, also known as granulocytic sarcoma, is a rare extramedullary manifestation of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It can present as proptosis when the orbit is involved. The best investigation to make the diagnosis of chloroma is a peripheral blood film, which helps identify the presence of myeloblasts. These cells are characteristic of AML and would confirm the diagnosis. In addition, chloromas are often associated with specific cytogenetic abnormalities, such as t(8;21) translocation.

While a bone marrow aspirate and flow cytometry are essential for definitive diagnosis, a peripheral blood smear is a practical, quick test to support the diagnosis. AML patients may also present with unusual symptoms such as "blueberry muffin" lesions, subcutaneous nodules, or infiltration of the gingiva, which can be helpful in diagnosing chloromas.

Incorrect Options:

  • Platelet count: Platelet counts may show thrombocytopenia in AML, but this is nonspecific and does not aid in the diagnosis of chloromas.
  • TLC/WBC Count: Total leukocyte count may show leukocytosis, but it does not provide specific information about the presence of chloromasor myeloblasts, making it insufficient for diagnosis.
  • Hemoglobin: Anemia is common in AML due to bone marrow failure, but hemoglobin levels are not specific for diagnosing chloromas or AML.

Key Takeaway:

  • Peripheral blood film is the best initial test to identify myeloblasts when chloroma is suspected.
  • Definitive diagnosis requires bone marrow aspirate, flow cytometry, and cytogenetic analysis.
  • Chloromas are extramedullary AML manifestationsand can cause symptoms such as proptosis, "blueberry muffin" lesions, and subcutaneous nodules in infants.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2654

questions.text: A boy presented with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. With the image provided, Identify the abnormal cell, viral pathogen associated and diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell, a pathognomonic feature of HL, is a large cell (15-45 μm in diameter) with multiple or multilobulated nuclei. This cell type is considered the hallmark of HL.

Infectious agents may be involved, such as human herpesvirus 6, cytomegalovirus, and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).


Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2657

questions.text: Hepatitis B subunit vaccine is derived from?
questions.solution:
The current subunit Hepatitis B vaccine is derived from surface antigen.

The hepatitis B vaccine is made by taking the part of the virus that makes surface protein ("surface protein gene") and putting it into yeast cells. The yeast cells then produce many copies of the protein that are subsequently used to make the vaccine.

Reference: IAP guidelines in Immunization, pg. 127

questions.text: Of the following, causes of neonatal seizures is/are?
questions.solution:
Hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyponatremia account for approximately 5% of neonatal seizures.


Reference: Cloherty and Starks manual of neonatal care, SA ed., pg. 849
